questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient?


	Thyroid scan
	Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)
	Thyroid function tests
	Ultrasound of neck
	Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,3,4 and 5 only

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a female with neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests a diagnosis of Grave’s disease. The essential investigations for this patient include thyroid function tests (TFT), ultrasound of the neck, thyroid scan, and anti-thyroid antibodies. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not essential in this case.

 

Grave’s Disease:

  • Onset typically between 20-50 years; rare before adolescence but occurs in the elderly.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Combination of genetics (e.g., HLA-DR, CTLA-4) and environmental factors (e.g., stress, iodine intake).
    • Associated with thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs), which activate the TSH receptor.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
  • Weight loss (despite increased appetite), or rarely, weight gain.
  • Hyperactivity, nervousness, fatigue, tremors, heat intolerance, sweating.
  • Cardiovascular: Sinus tachycardia, atrial fibrillation (in older patients), palpitation.
  • Neurological: Hyperreflexia, muscle weakness, rare chorea.
  • Skin: Warm, moist skin; palmar erythema, alopecia, hyperpigmentation.
  • GI: Increased stool frequency, diarrhea.
  • Bone: Osteopenia, mild hypercalcemia.
  • Specific to Grave’s disease:
    • Diffuse thyroid enlargement (thrill/bruit may be present).
    • Ophthalmopathy:
      • Proptosis, diplopia, and optic neuropathy.
    • Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema):
      • Indurated, pink-purple plaques with "orange-skin" appearance.
    • Acropachy (clubbing), rare.
  • Investigation:
  • TSH and Thyroid Hormones: (3)
    • Grave’s disease shows suppressed TSH levels with elevated total and unbound thyroid hormone levels.
    • T3 toxicosis (elevated T3 with normal T4) occurs in 2-5% of cases or more in areas with borderline iodine intake.
    • T4 toxicosis (elevated T4 with normal T3) can be seen with iodine-induced hyperthyroidism.
  • Antibody Testing: (5)
    • TPO antibodies or TRAb testing is useful for unclear cases but not routinely needed.
  • Associated Abnormalities:
    • Elevated bilirubin, liver enzymes, and ferritin.
    • Microcytic anemia and thrombocytopenia may occur.
  • Radionuclide scan and uptake (1) (e.g., 99mTc, 123I) differentiate Grave’s disease from thyroiditis, ectopic thyroid tissue, factitious thyrotoxicosis, toxic adenoma, or multinodular goiter.
  • Color-Flow Doppler Ultrasonography (4): Differentiates hyperthyroidism (increased blood flow) from destructive thyroiditis.
  • Treatment:
    • Antithyroid drugs: Propylthiouracil (provide symptomatic relief)
    • Radioiodine treatment (I131): Mainly used in elderly patients with surgical comorbidities or recurrence after surgery.

Thyroidectomy: Treatment of choice, especially when other methods fail or are contraindicated.

questions.text: What is a macrovascular complication that develops in the advanced stages of diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coronary artery disease

Explanation:

  • The macrovascular complication that develops in the advanced stages of diabetes is coronary artery disease.

Macrovascular Complications of Diabetes Mellitus

  • Major causes of morbidity and mortality in type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
  • Involves large blood vessels, leading to:
    • Coronary circulation: Myocardial ischaemia/infarction.
    • Cerebral circulation: Transient ischaemic attack, stroke.
    • Peripheral circulation: Claudication, ischaemia.

Key Points:

  • Excess mortality: Mainly due to myocardial infarction and stroke.
  • Accelerated atherosclerosis: Earlier onset and more severe in diabetics.
  • Amplified risk factors: Smoking, hypertension, dyslipidemia.
  • Metabolic syndrome: Common in type 2 diabetes, with additional cardiovascular risk factors due to insulin resistance. Criteria for metabolic syndrome are
    • Hypertension
    • High Fasting glucose
    • Elevated TG
    • Low HDL
    • Central obesity

Statistics:

Condition

Increased Rate in Diabetics

Cardiovascular death

1.7 times higher

Myocardial infarction

1.8 times greater

Stroke hospitalisation

1.5 times higher

Non-traumatic amputations

60% occur in diabetics

First cardiovascular event (type 1)

3 times higher in women, 2.3 times higher in men

Mechanisms linking hyperglycemia to macrovascular disease:

  • Increased vascular permeability: Due to high blood glucose.
  • Lipoprotein deposition: Hyperinsulinemia and hypertension increase atherogenic lipoprotein deposits in large vessels.

Risk Management:

  • Glycaemic control: Reduces both microvascular and macrovascular complications.
  • Blood pressure control: ACE inhibitors/ARBs are protective.
  • Dyslipidemia management: Statins are recommended to lower cardiovascular risks.
  • Lifestyle modifications: Smoking cessation, weight management, and regular physical activity are crucial.

Diabetic Microvascular Complications

  • Diabetic microangiopathy affects small blood vessels in diabetes, leading to significant morbidity and mortality.
  • Key clinical syndromes include:
    • Diabetic retinopathy (Option D)
    • Diabetic nephropathy (Option C)
    • Diabetic neuropathy

Foot ulcer (Option B) is a microvascular complication of diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Shock

Explanation: Shock is seen in pituitary apoplexy.

Pituitary apoplexy

Pathology

  • Acute intra-pituitary hemorrhage resulting in an endocrine emergency
  • It may arise spontaneously in preexisting adenomas, occur postpartum or be associated with conditions like diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or acute shock.
  • Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones may be ↓ or normal

Clinical features

  • Severe headache
  • Central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage
  • Signs of meningeal irritation
  • Loss of consciousness (secondary to adrenal insufficiency and shock) (Option C)
  • Bilateral visual changes
  • Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis)
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypotension (Option A)
  • Shock
  • Cardiovascular collapse

Management

  • High-dose glucocorticoids are the first line of treatment to correct adrenal insufficiency, stabilize blood pressure, and correct hypoglycemia.
  • Patients without evident visual loss or impaired consciousness can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids.
  • Urgent surgical decompression: Required for patients with significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness.
  • Monitoring: Visual recovery is inversely correlated with the duration of time after the acute event, so timely intervention is crucial.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the conditions is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

Explanation: The patient's symptoms of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain point towards hypothyroidism. The increase in TSH levels upon TRH administration indicates a lack of proper stimulus for TSH secretion from the hypothalamus.

 

Feature

Primary Hypothyroidism

Secondary Hypothyroidism

Definition

Thyroid gland dysfunction leads to inadequate thyroid hormone production

Pituitary dysfunction leads to insufficient TSH secretion

Causes
  • Autoimmune (Hashimoto's thyroiditis)
  • Iatrogenic (e.g., post-thyroidectomy, radiation)
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Medications (e.g., amiodarone, lithium)
  • Infiltrative diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis)
  • Food goitrogen → Cabbage, cassava.
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Pituitary surgery or radiation
  • Sheehan’s syndrome
  • Trauma
  • Genetic pituitary hormone deficiencies
  • Non-obstetric cause of pituitary damage called Simmonds's disease (AVM, tumor, HTN)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemochromatosis

Lab

TSH - ↑

Free T3/T4 - ↓

TSH - Normal or ↓

Free T3/T4 - ↓

Clinical Features
  • Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance
  • Dry skin, hair loss
  • Increased sleep
  • Bradycardia, constipation
  • Myxedema (puffy face, non-pitting edema)
  • Similar to primary hypothyroidism
  • Other pituitary hormone deficiencies (e.g., low cortisol, low LH/FSH)

Treatment

Levothyroxine (T4) replacement with dosage based on TSH levels

Levothyroxine (T4) replacement, but monitored by free T4 levels (since TSH is unreliable)

 

Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary (Option A) would result in elevated TSH and thyroid hormone levels, which is not consistent with the patient's low plasma TSH and hypothyroidism symptoms.

Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary (Option B): In pituitary hypothyroidism, TSH would be low due to the lack of pituitary secretion. However, unlike the hypothalamic case, TSH would not increase after TRH administration because the pituitary is unable to respond to TRH.

Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus (Option D): In hypothalamic hyperthyroidism, there would be a lack of feedback inhibition on the hypothalamus and pituitary, leading to elevated TSH and thyroid hormones. This is not consistent with the patient's low TSH and hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry, and blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/d,l and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Arterial blood gas

  • The child’s presentation with confusion, tachypnea (Kussmaul respirations), dry mucous membranes, hypotension, hyperglycemia, and positive urine ketones strongly points to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The next step is an arterial blood gas (ABG) to assess the severity of acidosis and guide management.

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA):

  • Is a hyperglycemic emergency characterized primarily by a triad of hyperglycemia, ketosis, and anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • Clinical Features:

Symptoms

Signs

  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Shortness of breath
  • Thirst, polyuria
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness
  • Leg cramps
  • Blurred vision
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension (postural or supine)
  • Tachypnea
  • Kussmaul respirations (air hunger)
  • Smell of acetone
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypothermia
  • Cold extremities/peripheral cyanosis
  • Abdominal tenderness (may resemble acute pancreatitis or surgical abdomen)
  • Lethargy/obtundation/cerebral oedema/possibly coma
  • Investigations of DKA:
    • Urine ketostix: Detects acetoacetate and acetate, but cannot detect ß-hydroxybutyrate.
    • Serum ß-hydroxybutyrate: Produced three times more than acetoacetate and is preferred for accurate diagnosis of DKA.
    • Random Blood Sugar: 250 - 600 mg/dL
    • Serum electrolytes:
      • Potassium:
        • Total body potassium deficiency of 3-6 mEq/kg in DKA occurs due to osmotic diuresis and vomiting.
        • Insulin shifts potassium intracellularly, lowering serum levels, and potassium correction with IV potassium chloride (KCl) should be done.
      • Sodium:
        • Serum sodium is reduced due to hyperglycemia: 1.6 meq/L reduction in sodium per 100 mg/dL rise in serum glucose.
        • Dilutional hyponatremia is common due to water driven into the intravascular space from inside cells.
    • Renal function test: Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine.
    • Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis:
      • pH: 6.8-7.3
      • pCO2: 20-30 mmHg
      • HCO3: <18 meq/L
      • Anion gap: Increased
      • Indicates DKA causes High anion gap metabolic acidosis.
    • Serum amylase and lipase: High
    • Total leukocyte count: Increased
    • Phosphorus and magnesium levels: Reduced, but not accurately shown due to hypovolemia and hyperglycemia.

2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours (Option A): Fluid resuscitation is essential in DKA, but without knowing the acid-base status through an ABG, it is not appropriate to start fluid therapy blindly. The ABG will guide the volume and rate of fluid administration based on the patient’s acidosis and hydration status.
Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour (Option B): Insulin therapy is critical, but it should be initiated after evaluating the patient’s acid-base status through an ABG. Correcting fluid and electrolyte imbalances is essential before starting insulin to avoid complications like hypokalemia and worsening dehydration.
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg (Option D): While insulin is needed, a bolus should not be given without first assessing the acid-base status and correcting fluid and electrolyte imbalances.

questions.text: A diabetic patient walks into your clinic and does “namaste”. The image is given below. What could be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cheiroarthropathy

Explanation:

  • Cheiroarthropathy is related to long-standing poor glycemic control and the accumulation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) in the skin and soft tissues.This can cause difficulty in fully extending the fingers, leading to a characteristic hand posture resembling the "namaste" gesture.

 

While flexor tenosynovitis (Option A) can occur in individuals with diabetes, it does not specifically explain the "namaste" gesture mentioned in the question.

 

Although Dupuytren's contracture (Option C) is associated with certain risk factors, such as family history and alcoholism, it is not directly related to the "namaste" gesture.

 

While ankylosis (Option D) can occur in various conditions, including certain forms of arthritis, trauma, or infection, it does not specifically explain the "namaste" gesture in the context of a diabetic patient.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are most commonly associated with elevated TSH levels and decreased T4 levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

Explanation:

  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder leading to chronic inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue. This results in decreased production of T3 and T4 hormones. As a compensatory mechanism, the pituitary gland releases more TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland, causing increased TSH levels.

Primary vs Secondary Hypothyroidism:

Feature

Primary Hypothyroidism

Secondary Hypothyroidism

Definition
  • Thyroid gland dysfunction leads to inadequate thyroid hormone production
  • Pituitary dysfunction leads to insufficient TSH secretion

Causes
  • Autoimmune (Hashimoto's thyroiditis)
  • Iatrogenic (e.g., post-thyroidectomy, radiation)
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Medications (e.g., amiodarone, lithium)
  • Infiltrative diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis)
  • Food goitrogen → Cabbage, cassava.
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Pituitary surgery or radiation
  • Sheehan’s syndrome
  • Trauma
  • Genetic pituitary hormone deficiencies
  • Non-obstetric cause of pituitary damage called Simmonds's disease (AVM, tumor, HTN)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemochromatosis

Lab
  • TSH - ↑;
  • Free T3/T4 - ↓
  • TSH - Normal or ↓;
  • Free T3/T4 - ↓

Clinical Features
  • Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance
  • Dry skin, hair loss
  • Bradycardia, constipation
  • Myxedema (puffy face, non-pitting edema)
  • Similar to primary hypothyroidism
  • Other pituitary hormone deficiencies (e.g., low cortisol, low LH/FSH)

Treatment
  • Levothyroxine (T4) replacement with dosage based on TSH levels
  • Levothyroxine (T4) replacement, but monitored by free T4 levels (since TSH is unreliable)

 

Hypoparathyroidism (Option A) is a condition characterized by inadequate production or secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.

While Pituitary Adenoma (Option B) can cause various hormonal imbalances, such as excessive production of prolactin (leading to hyperprolactinemia), it does not typically result in increased TSH and low T4 levels.

In Grave's disease (Option C), TSH levels are typically decreased due to the negative feedback mechanism resulting from high levels of thyroid hormones

questions.text: A female patient with type 1 DM and hypothyroidism presented with chronic oral mucocutaneous candidiasis for 5 years. She is diagnosed with autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) DM type-1 association is high

 

Explanation:

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM) is commonly associated with APS Type 2, it is less frequently seen in APS Type 1.
  • Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome (APS) Type 1 is also known as APECED (Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy, Candidiasis, and Ectodermal Dystrophy).
  • APS Type 1 is more associated with conditions like hypoparathyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

 

Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome (APS)

  • Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome iis a group of autoimmune disorders characterized by the immune system mistakenly attacking multiple endocrine glands, leading to hormonal imbalances.
  • It is classified into two main types

Feature

APS Type 1 (APECED)

APS Type 2 (Schmidt Syndrome)

Genetic Cause

Mutation in AIRE gene (Autoimmune Regulator)

Associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4 alleles

Inheritance Pattern

Autosomal recessive

Polygenic, complex inheritance

Age of Onset

Childhood onset (Option B ruled out)

Adulthood onset (20-40 years)

Clinical Features

Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, hypoparathyroidism, addison’s disease (Options C & D ruled out)

Addison’s disease, autoimmune thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus

Other Associated Conditions

Hypogonadism, alopecia, pernicious anemia, autoimmune enteropathy, keratoconjunctivitis

Vitiligo, myasthenia gravis, pernicious anemia, celiac disease

Endocrine Glands Affected

Parathyroid, adrenal, gonads, pancreatic islets, thyroid

Adrenal, thyroid, pancreatic islets

Diagnosis

Genetic testing for AIRE mutation, endocrine function tests

Endocrine function tests, autoantibody screening

Management

Hormone replacement (calcium & vitamin D for hypoparathyroidism, hydrocortisone for Addison’s), antifungal treatment for candidiasis

Hormone replacement (thyroxine for hypothyroidism, insulin for diabetes, corticosteroids for adrenal insufficiency)

Prognosis

Progressive, can be life-threatening without early treatment

Chronic but manageable with lifelong hormone therapy

APECED: Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy-Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy

questions.text:
In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes?


	HbA1c >6.5
	Fasting blood sugar >126mg/dl
	Random blood sugar >200mg/dl
	2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 and 4

Explanation: The initial screening for diabetes in a PHC typically involves fasting blood sugar levels >126 mg/dL and a 2-hour post-glucose load blood sugar.

 

The diagnosis of diabetes can be established using any of the following criteria:

  • Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG): ≥ 126 mg/dL (2) after an overnight fast. The result should be confirmed by repeating the test.
  • Random Plasma Glucose (RPG) (3): > 200 mg/dL, done only if the patient presents with symptoms of diabetes such as polyuria, polydipsia, ketoacidosis, or unexplained weight loss.
  • Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) (4): A two-hour plasma glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL after a 75-gram oral glucose challenge. For children, the test uses 1.75 gm/kg body weight.

 

HbA1c >6.5 (Option 1): HbA1c estimation is not typically used in primary health centers (PHC) in India due to limited resources, and it is usually only available in tertiary centers.

questions.text: What is the disease depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cushing’s syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations in the image is of Cushing’s syndrome which is caused due to prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids.

Cushing's syndrome

  • Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids.
  • Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma.
  • It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis.

Clinical Features of Cushing syndrome

  • Physical:
    • Weight gain and central obesity: Particularly around the face ("moon facies") and the back of the neck ("buffalo hump").
    • Skin changes: Thin and fragile skin prone to bruising, broad purple stretch marks, acne, and hirsutism.
    • Musculoskeletal Issues: Osteoporosis (leading to fractures, especially in the spine) (Option B), muscle weakness, proximal myopathy (difficulty climbing stairs or rising from a chair), and decreased deep tendon reflexes.
  • Metabolic: Glucose intolerance or diabetes and dyslipidemia (abnormal blood lipid levels).
  • Cardiovascular: Hypertension, hypokalemia, and oedema.
  • Reproductive: Decreased libido, and amenorrhea in women due to suppressed gonadotropin release.
  • Psychological: Irritability, emotional instability, depression, cognitive impairment, and in severe cases, psychosis.
  • Other features:
    • Increased susceptibility to infections, elevated white blood cell count, eosinopenia
    • Hypercoagulable state, increasing the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for treating Hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carbimazole

Explanation:

  • Carbimazole is the preferred medication for treating hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy. Carbimazole is a thyroid peroxidase inhibitor that has higher potency and longer half life than propylthiouracil. However, it crosses the placenta easily, and can cause aplasia cutis in the fetus. For this reason, Carbimazole is not administered during the 1st trimester.

Management of Hyperthyroidism in Pregnancy

Medical Management

First Trimester:

  • Propylthiouracil 100-300mg/day (three times daily)
  • Mechanism: Inhibits hormone synthesis + Thyroxine to Triiodothyronine conversion

Second/Third Trimester:

  • Methimazole 5-15mg/day (once daily)

Monitoring:

  • Thyroid Function Tests every 2-4 weeks
  • Thyroid Stimulating Hormone Receptor Antibodies: 18-22 weeks, 30-34 weeks
  • Target: Free Thyroxine upper normal, Thyroid Stimulating Hormone slightly low

Thyroid Storm Protocol
  1. Propanolol
  2. Potassium Iodide/Lugol's solution (60 minutes post-antithyroid drugs)
  3. Propylthiouracil/Methimazole administration
  4. Glucocorticoids
  5. Intensive care support
  6. Mortality: 20-30% if untreated

Teratogenicity

Methimazole Embryopathy:

  • Aplasia cutis
  • Choanal/esophageal atresia
  • Dysmorphic facies

PTU Associated:

  • Isolated anomalies
  • Situs inversus
  • Renal tract malformations

Contraindications
  • Radioactive iodine
  • First trimester thyroidectomy

Fetal Surveillance

Ultrasound markers:

  • Thyroid dimensions
  • Fetal heart rate (>160/min significant)
  • Growth parameters
  • Hydrops features
  • Bone maturation

 

Propyl Thiouracil (Option A): While propylthiouracil is the drug of choice during the first trimester of pregnancy due to lower risk of birth defects, it is not the preferred option during the second trimester. The switch to carbimazole is recommended after the first trimester due to its better efficacy and safety profile.

Sodium iodide (Option C): This medication is contraindicated during pregnancy as it can cross the placenta and affect fetal thyroid function. It can cause fetal hypothyroidism and goiter formation.

Radioactive iodine (Option D): Radioactive iodine is absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy as it readily crosses the placenta and can affect the fetal thyroid gland, potentially causing miscarriage or serious developmental issues. It should never be used during any stage of pregnancy.

questions.text: Addison's disease is characterized by all of the following symptoms except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hyperglycemia

Explanation:

  • Individuals with Addison's disease may experience hypoglycemia (Not Hyperglycemia) (low blood sugar) due to the inadequate production of cortisol, a hormone involved in regulating blood sugar levels.

Addison's disease refers to primary adrenocortical failure.

Etiology

  • Autoimmune: M/C/C Worldwide
    • Sporadic
    • Polyglandular syndromes
  • Tuberculosis: M/C/C in India
  • Histoplasmosis
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Bilateral adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Glucocorticoid insufficiency:
    • Weight loss, anorexia, malaise, weakness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, shock, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (Option B) (dilutional), hypercalcemia
  • Mineralocorticoid insufficiency:
    • Hypotension (Option D), shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia (Option C)
  • ACTH excess: Pigmentation
  • Adrenal androgen insufficiency: Decreased body hair and loss of libido, especially in females

questions.text: A comatose elderly patient with a weight of approximately 70 kilograms is presented to the emergency department. During examination, it was determined that the patient's serum glucose levels were 500mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.30, and there is an elevation in plasma ketones levels. However, the serum potassium levels are within the normal range. In order to treat this patient, which of the following should be added to the saline solution?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Insulin

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical features suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a potentially life-threatening complication of uncontrolled diabetes. Insulin is the mainstay of treatment in DKA as it helps lower blood glucose levels and suppresses ketone production.
  • DKA is characterized by hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of ketones in the blood. To manage DKA, it is crucial to address the underlying cause of hyperglycemia and correct metabolic derangements.

Updated Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (ISPAD 2022):

Contraindication of Insulin Drip:

  • Insulin should be withheld if the serum potassium level is below 3.3 mmol/L.
  • The target is to maintain serum potassium levels above 3.5 mmol/L (3.5 meq/L) to start the insulin drip.
  • Hypokalemia can lead to diaphragmatic paralysis and potentially result in respiratory arrest.

 

Bicarbonate (Option B) administration is generally not recommended for DKA unless the patient has severe acidosis (arterial pH <7.0). In this case, the arterial pH of 7.33 does not indicate severe acidosis, and thus, bicarbonate is not necessary.

Potassium (Option C) levels are normal in this patient, so additional potassium supplementation may not be required. However, regular monitoring of potassium levels is essential during the treatment of DKA, as insulin administration can cause a shift of potassium into the cells, leading to potential hypokalemia. If the patient's potassium levels decrease during treatment, appropriate potassium supplementation can be initiated.

The specific dose of 14 units of regular insulin intravenously (Option D) is not mentioned in the initial description and cannot be determined solely based on the given information. The insulin dosage should be individualized based on the patient's clinical condition, blood glucose levels, and response to treatment. It is typically administered as an initial bolus followed by continuous intravenous infusion.

questions.text: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Coxsackie B virus

Explanation: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is associated with coxsackie B virus infection.

Fulminant Diabetes:

  • A rapidly progressing subtype of type 1 diabetes, leading to severe hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis within a short time.
  • Pathogenesis: Exact cause unclear but likely involves genetic factors (HLA genes, especially DR4-DQ4) and viral infections (coxsackieviruses A4, A5, A6, B1, rotavirus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, human herpes virus (HHV)-6, and HHV-7)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Rapid onset: Average duration of hyperglycemic symptoms is 4 days.
    • Preceding symptoms: Common-cold-like symptoms and gastrointestinal symptoms are frequent.
    • Near-normal glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c): Despite severe hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis.
    • Absent C-peptide levels: Indicating no residual insulin secretion.
    • No autoantibodies against pancreatic β-cells: Unlike classic type 1 diabetes.
    • Elevated pancreatic enzyme levels.
    • Possible association with pregnancy.
  • Diagnosis: Based on rapid progression of hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and the above clinical features.
  • Treatment:
    • Immediate management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with:
      • Intravenous saline infusion.
      • Regular insulin therapy.
    • Long-term insulin therapy: Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion (CSII) or multiple daily injections (MDI).
  • Prognosis:
    • Without immediate treatment, death can occur within 24 hours.
    • Early recognition and prompt intervention are critical for survival.

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option A) (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes, characterized by hyperglycemia, ketone production, and metabolic acidosis. However, it is a consequence rather than a cause of fulminant diabetes.

Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma (Option C) is a life-threatening complication of diabetes, marked by extremely high blood sugar and severe dehydration. Unlike fulminant diabetes, it is typically seen in type 2 diabetes.

Autoimmune pancreatitis (Option D) is a rare form of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction. While it can lead to endocrine dysfunction, it does not cause the rapid and severe destruction of β-cells seen in fulminant type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: What would be the most suitable course of action for managing a 65-year-old male who presented with symptoms of weakness, lethargy, excessive cold intolerance, and slow ankle jerk? His thyroid function test (TFT) revealed a TSH level of 16 Mu/L (normal range: 0.4 - 4.0 mu / l), T4 level of 0.3 ng/dl (normal range: 0.6 - 1.6 ng / dl), and T3 level of 70 pg /dl.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome?
questions.solution:
Kallmann syndrome results from defective hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone synthesis and is associated with anosmia or hyposmia due to olfactory bulb agenesis or hypoplasia.

 

Kallmann Syndrome:

 

Pathophysiology:
Kallmann syndrome results from defective synthesis of hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). It is often accompanied by anosmia or hyposmia due to agenesis or hypoplasia of the olfactory bulb. This defect occurs due to mutations that impair the embryonic migration of GnRH neurons from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus.

 

Associated Features:

  • Neurological and Physical Abnormalities:
    • Anosmia or hyposmia
    • Color blindness
    • Optic atrophy
    • Nerve deafness
    • Cleft palate
    • Cryptorchidism
    • Renal abnormalities
    • Mirror movements (neurological)

 

Genetic Basis:

  • Initial discovery: X-linked KAL gene mutations.
  • Other genetic mutations include autosomal recessive (e.g., GPR54, KISS1) and dominant (e.g., FGFR1) mutations.
  • Additional genes: GNRH1, PROK2, PROKR2, CHD7, PCSK1, FGF8, NELF, WDR11, TAC3, TACR3, SEMA3E.
  • Some cases involve oligogenic mutations where multiple gene mutations contribute to the phenotype.

 

Clinical Presentation:

  • Males: Delayed puberty, hypogonadal features (e.g., micropenis, due to low testosterone during infancy).
  • Females: Primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual development.
  • Low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and sex steroids (testosterone or estradiol).

Diagnosis:

  • Typically, it is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction.
  • Repetitive GnRH administration restores pituitary gonadotropin responses, indicating a hypothalamic defect.

Treatment:

  • Males: Long-term human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or testosterone therapy to induce pubertal development and secondary sex characteristics.
  • Females: Cyclic estrogen and progestin therapy to induce secondary sexual development.
  • Fertility Restoration: Administration of gonadotropins or pulsatile GnRH delivery via a portable infusion pump.

Syndactyly in males (Option B): Associated with Apert or Poland syndromes, not Kallmann syndrome.

Precocious puberty in females (Option C): Kallmann syndrome causes delayed puberty, not precocious puberty, due to deficient GnRH secretion.

White forelock (Option D): A white forelock (poliosis) is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, a genetic disorder associated with sensorineural hearing loss, pigmentary abnormalities, and dystopia canthorum but not Kallmann syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pheochromocytoma

Explanation:

  • The elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine with the given clinical features suggests phaeochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Epidemiology
  • Estimated to occur in 2 to 8 of 1 million persons per year.
  • The mean age at diagnosis is 40 years, although the tumours can occur from early childhood until late in life.
  • The classic ‘rule of tens’ is 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal (Paragangliomas), and 10% metastatic. It is not used nowadays.

Etiopathogenesis
  • These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1,
    • multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and
    • Von-Hippel Lindau disease.
  • Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).
  • Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Norepinephrine is released continuously and can result in persistent hypertension, while epinephrine is released in a paroxysmal pattern resulting in tachyarrhythmias.
    • Ryanodine-2 receptors (RyR2).
    • Beta-2 adrenoceptors
    • Alpha(1)-adrenoreceptors

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • The dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection.
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

 

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

 

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the thyroid function test results for a middle-aged woman diagnosed with Grave's disease, presenting symptoms such as tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities?

choices.text: Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Low TSH levels

  • Low TSH levels is the correct answer. In Grave's disease, an autoimmune disorder causing overactivity of the thyroid gland, the production and release of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are increased. The elevated levels of thyroid hormones exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland, suppressing the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). Therefore, in Grave's disease, TSH levels are typically low.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Low free T4 levels: In Grave's disease, there is excessive production of thyroid hormones, resulting in elevated levels of free T4. Therefore, low free T4 levels would be an unlikely finding in this condition.

Option C- Low serum T3 levels: Grave's disease is characterized by increased production of both T3 and T4. Thus, low serum T3 levels would not be expected in this condition.

Option D- Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal: In Grave's disease, the thyroid gland is hyperactive and takes up iodine more than usual. This results in an increased radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) on a nuclear medicine scan, not a below-normal uptake.

questions.text: A patient presents with weight gain, thinning of hair, and dry skin. Diagnosis is Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Which antibody is seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anti-TPO antibody:

Explanation:

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas, and it is strongly associated with anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies. These antibodies cause autoimmune destruction of the thyroid gland.

Anti-TPO antibodies target the enzyme thyroid peroxidase, which is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis (oxidation and iodination of iodine, coupling of iodotyrosines). Their presence confirms autoimmune thyroid disease, especially Hashimoto’s. Other antibodies, like anti-thyroglobulin, may also be present but anti-TPO has the highest diagnostic relevance.

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis:

  • AKA Chronic autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis.
  • Epidemiology: More common in women, especially middle-aged.
  • Pathogenesis: Autoantibodies (anti-TPO, anti-thyroglobulin) → chronic inflammation → fibrosis → hypothyroidism.
  • Clinical features: Weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair thinning, constipation, menstrual irregularities.
  • Lab findings: High TSH, low free T4, positive anti-TPO antibodies.
  • Histopathology:
    • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration
    • Formation of germinal centers
    • Hurthle cells (large oxyphilic epithelial cells with granular cytoplasm) replacing follicular epithelium
    • Atrophic thyroid follicles with dense fibrosis in late stages

  • Treatment: Lifelong levothyroxine replacement.
  • Complications: Increased risk of thyroid lymphoma.

Incorrect Options:

Anti TSH (Option B) – Not seen in Hashimoto’s; would interfere with TSH action, not a diagnostic marker.

Anti TBG (Option C) – Antibodies against thyroxine-binding globulin are rare and not relevant for Hashimoto’s diagnosis.

Long-acting thyroid-stimulating antibody (Option D) – Seen in Graves’ disease, causes hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A patient has developed a cough and weight loss for the last 3 months. Biopsy of lung mass shows expression of chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which paraneoplastic syndrome will most likely occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – SIADH:

Explanation:

Chromogranin and synaptophysin positivity suggests a neuroendocrine tumor, such as small cell carcinoma of the lung. These tumors often produce ectopic ADH, leading to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

In SIADH, excessive ADH secretion causes water retention without corresponding sodium retention, resulting in dilutional hyponatremia and low plasma osmolality. Small cell lung carcinoma is notorious for secreting ectopic hormones, particularly ADH and ACTH. The presence of neuroendocrine markers confirms the tumor’s secretory nature.

Small Cell Carcinoma:

  • Origin: Neuroendocrine Kulchitsky cells in the lung.
  • Markers: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, neuron-specific enolase (NSE).
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes: SIADH (ADH), Cushing syndrome (ACTH), Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome (autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels).
  • Histology: Small cells with scant cytoplasm, nuclear molding, high mitotic count.
  • Prognosis: Aggressive, early metastasis; often unresectable at diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Combination chemotherapy ± radiotherapy; surgery rarely indicated.

questions.text: A patient presents with palpitations, headache, and sweating. His BP is 180/100 mmHg. 24-hour urinary metanephrine values are elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Pheochromocytoma:

Explanation:

  • Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla. Classic symptoms are episodic headache, sweating, and palpitations with hypertension. Elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines confirm catecholamine excess.
  • Pheochromocytomas arise from chromaffin cells derived from neural crest tissue. Excess secretion of epinephrine and norepinephrine causes paroxysmal hypertension and sympathetic overactivity. Metanephrines are catecholamine metabolites, and their measurement in a 24-hour urine sample or plasma is the most sensitive test for diagnosis.

Pheochromocytoma:

  • Origin: Chromaffin cells (adrenal medulla).
  • Rule of 10s: ~10% bilateral, 10% malignant, 10% extra-adrenal (paraganglioma), 10% in children.
  • Associations: MEN 2A, MEN 2B, von Hippel–Lindau disease, NF1.
  • Treatment: α-blockade (phenoxybenzamine) before β-blockade, then surgical resection.
  • Histology: Zellballen pattern (nests of cells with rich vascular stroma).

 

Incorrect Options:

Carcinoid tumor (Option A): Presents with flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm; diagnosis by urinary 5-HIAA, not metanephrines.

Carcinoid crisis (Option C): Severe complication of carcinoid tumor with profound hypotension and bronchospasm; unrelated to catecholamines.

Neuroblastoma (Option D): Pediatric tumor of adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain; elevated HVA/VMA (dopamine metabolites), not metanephrines in adults.

questions.text: A known case of hyperthyroidism, who is not on medication, is scheduled for total thyroidectomy. The PAC check was not done properly. What is the leading complication that can occur during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Arrhythmia

Explanation:

  • In uncontrolled hyperthyroidism, catecholamine sensitivity is increased, predisposing the patient to severe intraoperative arrhythmias, especially during surgical manipulation of the thyroid gland.
  • A patient with untreated hyperthyroidism undergoing thyroidectomy is at high risk of thyroid storm, precipitated by surgical stress. This can manifest with tachyarrhythmias, hyperthermia, and hypertension. Arrhythmia (especially atrial fibrillation or supraventricular tachycardia) is the most immediate and dangerous intraoperative complication.
  • Proper preoperative control with antithyroid drugs, β-blockers, and adequate preparation is essential.

Incorrect Options:

Hyperthermia (Option A): Can occur in thyroid storm but is not the leading intraoperative danger; arrhythmia is more acutely life-threatening.

Hypothermia (Option B): Not typically associated with hyperthyroidism; more a concern in prolonged surgeries in cold OR environments.

Hypothyroidism (Option D): Develops postoperatively, not during surgery.

questions.text: Patient presents with hypertension and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. CT scan shows a mass over the kidney with elevated ARR. What is the next best step for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Adrenalectomy:

Explanation:

  • This patient likely has primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn’s syndrome) due to an adrenal adenoma. In unilateral disease confirmed by imaging and biochemistry (elevated Aldosterone–Renin Ratio), surgical adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice.
  • Hypertension + hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis + high ARR + adrenal mass suggests unilateral aldosterone-producing adenoma. After confirming lateralization (often with adrenal venous sampling in some protocols), the definitive treatment is laparoscopic adrenalectomy. Medical management with mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (spironolactone/eplerenone) is reserved for bilateral adrenal hyperplasia or non-surgical candidates.

ACTH stimulation test (Option C): Used for adrenal insufficiency diagnosis, not hyperaldosteronism.

Dexamethasone suppression test (Option D): Used for diagnosing Cushing’s syndrome.

questions.text: A female presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. Serum prolactin is elevated. MRI shows pituitary adenoma. Best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bromocriptine

Explanation:

The patient has hyperprolactinemia due to a pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma). Hyperprolactinemia → suppresses GnRH → ↓ LH/FSH → menstrual irregularities and infertility. First-line treatment for prolactinomas is dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine or Cabergoline) as they inhibit prolactin secretion and can shrink the tumor. Bromocriptine is safe in women desiring pregnancy.

Surgery (trans-sphenoidal resection) is reserved for drug-resistant or compressive symptoms (e.g., visual loss).

Prolactinoma:

  • Causes:
    • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
    • Drugs: antipsychotics, metoclopramide
    • Hypothyroidism (↑ TRH → ↑ prolactin)
  • Symptoms:
    • Women: amenorrhea, galactorrhea, infertility
    • Men: decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, gynecomastia
    • Mass effect: headaches, bitemporal hemianopia if the optic chiasm is compressed
  • Diagnosis: serum prolactin, MRI brain with pituitary protocol
  • Treatment: dopamine agonists (Bromocriptine, Cabergoline) → surgery if not responsive

Incorrect Options:

Letrozole (Option B) – Aromatase inhibitor for estrogen-dependent breast cancer and infertility, not first-line for prolactinoma.

Tamoxifen (Option C) – Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used in breast cancer, unrelated to prolactinomas.

Goserelin (Option D) – GnRH agonist used in prostate/breast cancer and endometriosis, not for prolactinoma.

questions.text: Hyperpigmentation in Addison’s disease is due to increased secretion of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ACTH

In primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease), destruction of the adrenal cortex leads to low cortisol and aldosterone. The pituitary compensates by secreting more ACTH from the precursor proopiomelanocortin (POMC), which also produces melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).

  • MSH stimulates melanin production, causing skin and mucosal hyperpigmentation.

Addison's disease refers to primary adrenocortical failure:

Etiology

  • Autoimmune: M/C/C Worldwide
    • Sporadic
    • Polyglandular syndromes
  • Tuberculosis: M/C/C in India
  • Histoplasmosis
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Bilateral adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Glucocorticoid insufficiency
    • Weight loss, anorexia, malaise, weakness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, shock, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (dilutional), hypercalcemia
  • Mineralocorticoid insufficiency:
    • Hypotension, shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • ACTH excess: Pigmentation
  • Adrenal androgen insufficiency: Decreased body hair and loss of libido, especially in females

Cortisol (Option A): Deficient in Addison’s disease; low levels stimulate ACTH production but do not directly cause pigmentation.

Aldosterone (Option C): Deficient in Addison’s disease; loss leads to hyperkalemia and hypotension, not pigmentation.

Renin (Option D): Elevated due to hypovolemia, but has no role in pigmentation.

questions.text: A patient presents with palpitations, headache and diaphoresis + elevated 24 hour urine metanephrine levels. Which of the following drugs can be used both preoperatively and intraoperatively for control of BP?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Labetalol

  • Labetalol is a combined α- and β-adrenergic blocker that can be used both preoperatively and intraoperatively in pheochromocytoma to control hypertension. While non-selective α-blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine) is preferred initially to prevent hypertensive crises, labetalol can be used when both α- and β-blockade are desired and during surgery to manage BP surges.

Phenoxybenzamine (Option A): An irreversible α-blocker, used mainly preoperatively, but not ideal intraoperatively due to prolonged action and inability to titrate rapidly.

Esmolol (Option B): A short-acting β1-blocker, used after adequate α-blockade if tachycardia persists; not used alone for BP control in pheochromocytoma.

Clonidine (Option C): Central α2 agonist, not first-line for pheochromocytoma BP control; may reduce sympathetic outflow but less effective for catecholamine surges.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic patient is currently on Metformin and Insulin Glargine. His HbA1c is 8.2%, indicating suboptimal glycemic control. Echocardiography reveals a reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 35%. Which of the following is the most appropriate agent to add to his current regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Empagliflozin

Explanation: Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that not only lowers blood glucose but also has proven cardiovascular benefits, particularly in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), irrespective of diabetes status.

  • In this diabetic patient with suboptimal glycemic control and EF 35%, empagliflozin is the preferred add-on as it reduces hospitalizations for heart failure and improves survival.

Pioglitazone (Option A): Causes fluid retention and can worsen heart failure — contraindicated in EF <40%.

Glimepiride (Option B): A sulfonylurea that increases hypoglycemia risk and offers no cardiovascular benefit.

Sitagliptin (Option C): A DPP-4 inhibitor with neutral cardiovascular effects; not first choice for HFrEF.

questions.text: A patient presents with salt wasting, craving, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and skin pigmentation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Addison’s disease

Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Addison’s disease,

Addison’s disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is characterized by:

  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency → salt wasting, salt craving, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis.
  • Glucocorticoid deficiency → weakness, fatigue, weight loss.
  • Increased ACTH due to loss of cortisol negative feedback → skin hyperpigmentation from excess melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH).

Investigations
  • Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency)
  • Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency.
  • Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency)
  • Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women
  • Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative.

Management

1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is preferred, and Prednisolone and dexamethasone may also be used.

2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone

Addisonian crisis

An Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening medical emergency that occurs when there is a severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone. It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery).

Management: IV Hydrocortisone

Cushing’s syndrome (Option B): Due to cortisol excess; presents with central obesity, moon face, hypertension, hyperglycemia—not salt wasting or hyperkalemia.

Conn’s syndrome (Option C): Primary hyperaldosteronism; causes sodium retention, hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis—not hyperkalemia or pigmentation.

Pheochromocytoma (Option D): Catecholamine-secreting tumor; presents with episodic headache, sweating, tachycardia, hypertension—not salt wasting or hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: A known type 1 diabetic presents with glucose 799 mg/dL, Na⁺ 128 mEq/L, Cl⁻ 88 mEq/L, and signs of dehydration. Which of the following is NOT used in the initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3% Saline

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation points towards DKA

  • In DKA, the initial management focuses on:
    • Fluid resuscitation with isotonic saline (0.9% NaCl) to correct dehydration.
    • Insulin infusion to correct hyperglycemia and ketosis.
    • Potassium monitoring and replacement as insulin therapy and fluids can cause hypokalemia.

Updated Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (ISPAD 2022):

3% hypertonic saline is not indicated unless there is severe symptomatic hyponatremia with neurological symptoms (usually Na⁺ < 120 mEq/L and acute onset). In this case, hyponatremia is dilutional and corrects with normal saline and DKA management.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypotension, hyponatremia and blackening of the knuckles and perioral area. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Addison’s Disease:

  • Addison’s Disease:

    • Symptoms:

      • Hypotension: Due to insufficient cortisol production affecting blood pressure.

      • Hyponatremia: Caused by low aldosterone levels, leading to reduced sodium reabsorption.

      • Hyperpigmentation: Characterized by darkening of the skin, including knuckles and perioral areas, due to increased ACTH levels stimulating melanocytes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conn Syndrome: Characterized by primary hyperaldosteronism, which typically leads to hypertension, hypokalemia (low potassium), and metabolic alkalosis, but not usually associated with hyperpigmentation or hyponatremia.

Option B - Cushing’s Syndrome: Results from excess cortisol production and can present with hypertension, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia. Hyperpigmentation is not a common feature; instead, you might see features such as easy bruising and a “moon facies.”

Option C - Primary ACTH Deficiency: Leads to low cortisol levels but not usually associated with hyperpigmentation. Patients may experience symptoms of adrenal insufficiency, but hyperpigmentation is more characteristic of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease) rather than ACTH deficiency.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with proximal muscle weakness, purple stretch marks, obesity, and easy bruising. What is the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypercortisolism:

  • The presented scenario suggests Cushing syndrome with features like weight gain, purple striae, and proximal myopathy. Hypercortisolism is the underlying condition in Cushing syndrome. It's primarily caused by chronic over-production of cortisol by the adrenal glands, often due to adrenal or pituitary tumors. Pituitary-dependent cortisol excess, termed Cushing’s disease, accounts for about 80% of cases of Cushing syndrome.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with symptoms of headache, renal stones, and abdominal pain. Serum calcium is low and PTH is high. Which of the following hormone and associated disease might be causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mineral and bone disorders:

  • Low calcium levels and elevated PTH levels indicate Mineral and Bone Disorders. In chronic kidney disease-mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD), essential changes encompass hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, deficient serum vitamin D levels, and heightened secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), culminating in secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parathyroid and Primary hyperparathyroidism: In primary hyperparathyroidism, there is an elevation in serum calcium levels, which contrasts with the decreased levels seen in the presented case. Additionally, episodic headaches are a common symptom in this condition.

Option B - Catecholamines and Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma typically presents with hypertension and diaphoresis, symptoms not mentioned in the provided case.

Option C - Thyroxine and Hypothyroidism: Hyperthyroidism typically presents with symptoms such as weight gain and cold intolerance, which contrast with those described in the provided case.

questions.text: Which medication is recommended as the primary treatment for high blood sugar in a 19-year-old woman with a medical history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, who has been brought to the emergency room due to symptoms of confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain, and subsequently diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
• In the management of DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis), the main goal is to lower the blood glucose level and correct the acid-base and electrolyte imbalances. Regular insulin is the drug of choice for the management of hyperglycemia in DKA. It is a fast-acting insulin that is given intravenously and has a rapid onset of action, which helps to lower the blood glucose level quickly.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option b: Lente insulin is a combination of short-acting and long-acting insulin, which is used for the management of type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. It has a delayed onset of action and is not effective for the rapid correction of hyperglycemia in DKA. 
  • Option c: 70/30 insulin is a combination of intermediate-acting and short-acting insulin, which is used for the management of type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is not appropriate for the rapid correction of hyperglycemia in DKA.
  • Option d: Glyburide is an oral hypoglycemic agent that is used for the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by stimulating the release of insulin from the pancreas. It is not appropriate for the management of DKA as it does not lower the blood glucose level quickly enough to be effective in the treatment of this condition.

questions.text: All of the below are features of Conn's syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome.
    • Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by autonomous aldosterone production from the adrenal glands. The condition leads to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubules. It is characterized by Hypertension, Hypokalemia and Metabolic Alkalosis (leading to muscle cramps).
    • The pathophysiology involves excess aldosterone stimulating the ENaC channel, resulting in increased sodium and water reabsorption while promoting urinary loss of potassium and hydrogen ions.

Conn Syndrome / Primary Hyperaldosteronism

Definition

Primary hyperaldosteronism characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion from adrenal glands with suppressed plasma renin

Epidemiology
  • Most common cause of secondary hypertension (6-20% of adult hypertensive patients)
  • Higher prevalence in resistant hypertension (up to 30%)
  • 2x more common in women

Etiology
  • Aldosterone-producing adenoma (50-60%)
  • Bilateral idiopathic adrenal hyperplasia
  • Aldosterone-producing adrenal carcinoma (1%)
  • Familial hyperaldosteronism (Types 1-3)

Pathophysiology
  • ↑ Aldosterone → ↑ Na+ reabsorption → plasma volume expansion
  • ↑ K+ excretion → hypokalemia
  • Can lead to tissue inflammation and fibrosis in heart, kidneys, vasculature

Clinical Features
  • Resistant hypertension
  • Muscle weakness/cramping
  • Fatigue
  • Headaches
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • NO edema (due to spontaneous natriuresis)

Lab Findings
  • ↓ K+ (can be normal in up to 38%)
  • ↑ Na+
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • ↑ Urinary K+ excretion (>30 mmol/day)
  • Suppressed plasma renin
  • ↑ Aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR)

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Initial screening: ARR >40
  • Confirmatory tests:
    • Salt loading test
    • Fludrocortisone suppression test
    • Captopril suppression test
  • Imaging: CT scan for adenoma
  • Adrenal venous sampling for lateralization

Treatment
  • Adenoma: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Bilateral hyperplasia: Medical management
  • Medical options:
    • Spironolactone (first-line)
    • Eplerenone
    • Amiloride

Prognosis
  • Surgery: 30-60% cure rate for adenomas
  • High morbidity/mortality if untreated
  • May need long-term BP monitoring

High-Yield Associations
  • Normal K+ doesn't exclude diagnosis
  • No edema despite hyperaldosteronism
  • Screen all resistant hypertension cases

Metabolic alkalosis (Option A) is a characteristic feature of Conn's syndrome. This occurs due to increased urinary loss of hydrogen ions and bicarbonate retention, leading to alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis is actually one of the hallmark features of this condition.

Hypertension (Option C) is a primary manifestation of Conn's syndrome. This develops due to increased sodium and water reabsorption leading to volume expansion. The increased blood volume and sodium retention directly contribute to elevated blood pressure.

Muscle cramps (Option D) are commonly seen in patients with Conn's syndrome. These occur due to hypokalemia. The low potassium levels affect muscle function and can lead to weakness, fatigue, and cramping.

Pheochromocytoma (Option D): Pheochromocytoma is actually associated with MEN-II/Sipple syndrome & MEN-III, not MEN-1.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of diabetes ketoacidosis, except?

choices.text: Serum glucose of more than 250 mg

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Serum potassium less than 3.5 mEq: 

  • Serum potassium below 3.5 mEq can occur in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) but isn't part of diagnostic criteria. In DKA, patients are often potassium-depleted, yet plasma potassium levels may not fully indicate a total deficit. Initially, levels might even be elevated due to factors like water loss and potassium shifting. However, treatment can lead to a rapid drop in plasma potassium due to fluid dilution, insulin-induced movement into cells, and ongoing renal loss.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serum glucose of more than 250 mg: Serum glucose above 250 mg/dL is a diagnostic criterion for DKA. This leads to osmotic diuresis, causing dehydration and electrolyte loss, especially sodium and potassium.

Option B - Anion gap of more than 10-12: An anion gap above 10-12 is a diagnostic criterion for DKA. It occurs because bicarbonate is replaced by β-hydroxybutyric acid and acetoacetic acid, reducing the sum of bicarbonate and chloride concentrations and raising the anion gap.

Option C - Serum potassium less than 3.5 mEq: Serum bicarbonate below 15 mmol/L is a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Ketosis causes blood ketone accumulation, resulting in metabolic acidosis. This shift forces hydrogen ions into cells, displacing potassium ions.

questions.text: A diabetic patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue and frequent urination. On examination vitals are stable and an HbA1c is done. What is the cut-off percentage used for determining controlled diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 7.0

Explanation:

  • According to the American College of Physicians, the target HbA1c for determining controlled diabetes is <7.0% for adults with diabetes. This value represents optimal glycemic control, though it may be adjusted to <8.0% in elderly frail patients.

Glycated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) effectively assesses overall glycemic control and is suitable for diagnosing diabetes in asymptomatic individuals.

HbA1c prediction in undiagnosed individuals:

  • < 5.7% : Normal
  • 5.7% - 6.5% : Pre-diabetic
  • > 6.5% : Diabetic

For patients with existing diabetes, HbA1c is used to evaluate the degree of effective control on diabetes.

The cutoffs recommended by ACP for monitoring effective control include:

  • HbA1c < 7.0%
  • Preprandial capillary plasma glucose between 80-130 mg/dL
  • Postprandial capillary plasma glucose <180 mg/dL.

6.0 (Option A), 6.5 (Option B) & 7.5 (Option D) are incorrect values according to ACP recommendation.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs can cause glucosuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Empagliflozin

Explanation:

  • Empagliflozin belongs to the class of SGLT-2 inhibitors that work by blocking sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 in the proximal convoluted tubules of the nephron. This mechanism prevents the reabsorption of glucose and sodium back into the bloodstream, leading to glucosuria.
  • The drug provides multiple benefits including reduced progression of chronic kidney disease, diuretic effects through sodium loss, and blood pressure reduction of 3-6 mmHg. However, these drugs are contraindicated in patients with eGFR <45 ml/min due to reduced efficacy and risk of urinary tract infections.

Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) Inhibitors

Examples
  • Canagliflozin
  • Dapagliflozin
  • Empagliflozin

Mechanism of Action

  • Blocks reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule, promoting the excretion of sodium and glucose in urine

Indications
  • Reduce progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD)
  • Diuretic effect, leading to sodium loss
  • Reduces systolic blood pressure (SBP) by 3-6 mmHg
  • Cardiorenal advantage
  • CHF to decrease mortality with or without DM

Side Effects
  • Increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Glucosuria (leading to UTIs and vulvovaginal candidiasis)
  • Dehydration (orthostatic hypotension)
  • Weight loss

Contraindications
  • Not recommended if estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) < 45 ml/min
  • Use with caution in renal insufficiency (decreased efficacy with decreased GFR)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Glimepiride (Option A): This sulfonylurea medication works by stimulating insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, causing hypoglycemia and weight gain. It does not cause glucosuria as its mechanism of action is focused on increasing insulin secretion.

Exenatide (Option B): This GLP-1 receptor agonist binds to GLP-1 receptor in pancreatic beta-cells in turn increasing insulin secretion and suppressing glucagon secretion. Its actions include delayed gastric emptying, induces early satiety (weight loss) & stabilizes atherosclerotic plaque (reduction in cardiovascular mortality). Its mechanism does not involve renal glucose reabsorption thus does not cause glucosuria.

Acarbose (Option C): This alpha-glucosidase inhibitor works by controlling post-prandial glucose spikes through reduced carbohydrate absorption in the intestine. It may cause abdominal bloating and diarrhea but does not affect renal glucose handling or cause glucosuria.

questions.text: In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, what characterizes stage 3 of beta-cell destruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Symptomatic hyperglycemia:

  • In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (DM), the progression of beta-cell destruction typically occurs in stages:
    • Stage 1: Autoimmune destruction of beta cells, but no symptoms are present. Normal blood glucose levels.
    • Stage 2: Progressive beta-cell destruction with dysglycemia (impaired glucose metabolism) but no symptoms of hyperglycemia yet.
    • Stage 3: Significant beta-cell destruction leading to symptomatic hyperglycemia. Patients will present with symptoms such as polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss due to elevated blood glucose levels.
  • At Stage 3, the destruction is advanced enough that insulin production is insufficient to maintain normal glucose levels, resulting in symptomatic hyperglycemia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dysglycemic symptomatic: Dysglycemia refers to abnormal glucose levels, which could be either high (hyperglycemia) or low (hypoglycemia). In Type 1 DM, Stage 3 is characterized specifically by symptomatic hyperglycemia, not just dysglycemia.

Option C - Normoglycemic symptomatic: Normoglycemic means normal blood glucose levels. In Stage 3 of Type 1 DM, the patient is not normoglycemic; instead, they are experiencing symptomatic hyperglycemia due to the loss of beta-cell function.

Option D - Dysglycemic asymptomatic: Dysglycemia asymptomatic implies abnormal glucose levels without symptoms. In Stage 3 of Type 1 DM, patients are symptomatic due to hyperglycemia, so this option does not fit the stage described.

questions.text: A young woman presents with weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors. On examination, she has exophthalmos. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Graves' disease:

  • Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that leads to hyperthyroidism. Symptoms such as weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors are all characteristic of an overactive thyroid. Exophthalmos (protrusion of the eyes) is a hallmark feature of Graves' disease, distinguishing it from other thyroid conditions. This makes Graves' disease the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms and findings.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by tremors, bradykinesia (slowness of movement), rigidity, and postural instability. It does not typically present with weight loss, heat intolerance, or exophthalmos, which are more suggestive of a hyperthyroid state.

Option C - Addison's disease: Addison's disease is a disorder of adrenal insufficiency characterized by symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and salt cravings. It does not typically present with tachycardia, heat intolerance, tremors, or exophthalmos, which are indicative of hyperthyroidism rather than adrenal insufficiency.

Option D - Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative condition that primarily affects memory and cognitive function. It does not cause weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, tremors, or exophthalmos, which are not associated with its clinical presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic test for carcinoid tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate that carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete serotonin, which is metabolized to 5-HIAA and excreted in urine.

Diagnosis of Carcinoid Syndrome

Diagnostic Method

Details

  • Primary diagnostic test
  • 24-hour urine collection
  • Measures serotonin metabolites
  • Can be challenging if patient is consuming serotonin-rich foods (e.g., salmon, eggs)

  • Also known as OctreoScan
  • Can confirm presence of somatostatin receptors
  • Helps in tumor localization

68Ga-DOTATATE PET Scan
  • More sensitive imaging technique
  • Uses radioactive gallium-68
  • Helps predict response to treatment
  • Particularly useful for NET imaging

Chromogranin A
  • Blood test biomarker
  • Elevated in metastatic disease
  • Should be interpreted with caution in patients with renal dysfunction, patients taking PPIs
  • Not diagnostic alone, but helpful in monitoring

Clinical Symptoms
  • Flushing episodes (2-5 mins)
  • Diarrhea
  • Wheezing
  • Heart valve problems
  • Abdominal pain
  • Telangiectasia

24-hour urinary catecholamines (Option A): This test is used to diagnose pheochromocytoma and other catecholamine-secreting tumors, not carcinoid tumors. Catecholamines are not characteristic of carcinoid syndrome.

Serum calcitonin levels (Option B): This test is used to diagnose medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is a different type of neuroendocrine tumor. Calcitonin is unlikely to be elevated in carcinoid syndrome.

Serum chromogranin A (Option C): While chromogranin A can be elevated in some neuroendocrine tumors, it is not specific for carcinoid tumors and is not the diagnostic test of choice. It may be used as a supplementary marker but not for primary diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is the best for assessing long-term control of diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glycosylated Hemoglobin

Explanation:

  • Glycosylated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) is the gold standard for monitoring long-term glycemic control in diabetic patients. This test provides a reliable measure of average blood glucose levels over the preceding 2-3 months, corresponding to the lifespan of red blood cells.
  • HbA1c testing is particularly valuable because it is not affected by daily fluctuations in blood glucose levels and does not require fasting. The test measures the percentage of hemoglobin molecules that have glucose attached to them, providing a more stable and accurate reflection of overall glycemic control.
  • It provides a more comprehensive view of glucose levels compared to other tests, with a diagnostic threshold of ≥ 48 mmol/mol (6.5%), making it ideal for early detection, particularly in patients with risk factors like obesity and family history.

HbA1c evaluation:

  • < 5.7% : Normal
  • 5.7% - 6.5% : Pre-diabetic
  • > 6.5% : Diabetic

Other Investigations for Diabetes Mellitus:

Blood Glucose Tests:

  • Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG)
    • Measures glucose after an overnight fast.
    • Diagnostic threshold: ≥ 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L).
    • Simple, cost-effective, and widely available.
  • Random Plasma Glucose (RPG)
    • Measures glucose at any time, irrespective of meals.
    • Diagnostic threshold: ≥ 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L).
    • Useful for immediate diagnosis in symptomatic patients.
  • Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT)
    • Fasting glucose was measured, followed by a 75 g glucose drink, then re-measured after 2 hours.
    • Diagnostic threshold: ≥ 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L).
    • More time-consuming; identifies impaired glucose tolerance.

 

Glycated Albumin (Option B) measurement reflects average blood glucose levels over only 2-3 weeks due to albumin's shorter half-life of approximately 20 days. While useful for short-term monitoring, it doesn't provide the comprehensive long-term assessment that HbA1c offers.

Serum Fructosamine (Option C) testing, similar to glycated albumin, provides information about glycemic control over the previous 2-3 weeks. This test measures glycated plasma proteins and is sometimes used when HbA1c results may be unreliable, such as in patients with hemoglobinopathies.

Urine Sugar (Option D) testing is not reliable for assessing long-term glucose control as it is influenced by multiple factors including renal threshold, hydration status, and concurrent medications. Urine glucose appears only when blood glucose exceeds the renal threshold, making it an inadequate measure of overall glycemic control.

questions.text: A patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism, characterized by decreased TSH levels and elevated free T3 and T4. Which of the following statements about this condition is NOT true?

choices.text: The condition will improve simultaneously with improvement in the thyrotoxic state.
In 10% of cases, the condition is present without hyperthyroidism.
Severe disease can cause vision loss.
No specs criteria is used for this condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The condition will improve simultaneously with improvement in the thyrotoxic state:

  • This statement is not true because the condition being referred to is likely Graves' ophthalmopathy (thyroid eye disease), which does not always improve simultaneously with the resolution of the thyrotoxic state. The eye manifestations can persist or even worsen independently of the thyroid hormone levels.
