Options B, C and D are true statements regarding hyperthyroidism and Graves' ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: A patient with a history of Wilson's disease presents with neurological manifestations. Which of the following is the best diagnostic modality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hepatic parenchymal demonstration of copper:

  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by excessive accumulation of copper in various body tissues, primarily the liver and brain. The best diagnostic modality to confirm Wilson's disease, especially in the presence of neurological manifestations, is hepatic parenchymal demonstration of copper. This is usually done by performing a liver biopsy to measure the hepatic copper concentration, which is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serum ceruloplasmin: While serum ceruloplasmin is often low in Wilson's disease, it is not the most reliable diagnostic tool, as ceruloplasmin levels can be low in other conditions and may be normal in some patients with Wilson's disease.

Option B - Urinary copper excretion: This test measures 24-hour urinary copper excretion and is elevated in Wilson's disease, but it is not as definitive as hepatic copper measurement. It is useful as part of the diagnostic workup but not the best single test.

Option D - Anti-tissue transglutaminase (Anti-tTG) antibody: This antibody is associated with celiac disease and is not relevant to the diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family reported a previous history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor made a tentative diagnosis based on the clinical symptoms. What would be the most appropriate investigative method to establish a conclusive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Sestamibi scan

  • The clinical presentation suggests primary hyperparathyroidism, characterized by the triad of bone pain (from increased bone resorption), abdominal cramps (from hypercalcemia), and neuropsychiatric symptoms (manifesting as abnormal behavior).
  • Sestamibi scan is the preferred imaging modality for localizing parathyroid adenomas, which are the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism.

Sestamibi scan (Tc-99): Localize the parathyroid adenoma.

MRI (Option A) while capable of identifying soft tissue masses, is not the first-line imaging modality for parathyroid adenoma detection. MRI is more expensive, time-consuming, and does not offer any significant advantage over sestamibi scanning for parathyroid imaging.

Ultrasonogram (Option B) can identify parathyroid masses but has limitations in detecting ectopic parathyroid tissue and is highly operator-dependent. It may be used as a complementary imaging technique but is not the most sensitive primary diagnostic tool.

CT scan (Option D) provides detailed anatomical imaging but lacks the functional information provided by sestamibi scanning. While CT may be useful for surgical planning, it is not the initial imaging modality of choice for diagnosing parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: In a 60-year-old male, what is the primary etiology typically associated with Cushing's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Pituitary microadenoma

  • Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is most commonly caused by a pituitary microadenoma. This condition is characterized by a benign ACTH-secreting tumor in the pituitary gland, leading to hypercortisolism through increased ACTH production. The excessive ACTH stimulates the adrenal glands to produce higher levels of cortisol, resulting in the classic features of Cushing's syndrome.

Cushing's syndrome- Definition and Causes

Definition:
  • Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids.
  • Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma.
  • It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis.

Causes:

Cushing's syndrome can be caused by various factors, categorised as ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent.

I) ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome accounts for approximately 90% of cases.

  • Cushing's disease (ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma) is the most common cause.
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome occurs when a non-pituitary tumour secretes ACTH.

II) ACTH-independent Cushing's Syndrome constitutes the remaining 10% of cases.

  • Adrenocortical adenoma is the most prevalent cause, accounting for 5–10% of all cases.
  • Rare causes include:
    • Primary bilateral macronodular adrenal hyperplasia (PBMAH)
    • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease (PPNAD)
    • McCune-Albright syndrome

Small-cell lung cancer (Option A) can produce ACTH or ACTH-like substances, resulting in paraneoplastic Cushing's syndrome. However, it is not the most common cause of Cushing's disease in an elderly patient. Small-cell lung cancer typically presents with additional respiratory symptoms and a more rapid onset of hypercortisolism features.

Adrenal tumor (Option B) can cause Cushing's syndrome through autonomous cortisol production by either an adenoma or carcinoma. However, these tumors bypass the pituitary-adrenal axis and typically suppress ACTH levels, unlike the elevated ACTH seen in Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary microadenoma.

Ectopic ACTH syndrome (Option C) occurs when non-pituitary tumors (such as lung, pancreas, or thymus) produce ACTH. While this is a recognized cause of Cushing's syndrome, it is less common than pituitary microadenomas as the primary cause of Cushing's disease in older adults. Ectopic ACTH syndrome typically presents with more rapid onset and severe metabolic derangements.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urine metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Pheochromocytoma

  • The clinical manifestations indicate pheochromocytoma based on the classic triad of symptoms and elevated urinary metanephrines. Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor that produces excessive amounts of catecholamines, leading to paroxysmal symptoms including sudden onset headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated levels of urinary metanephrines, which is considered the most sensitive diagnostic test for pheochromocytoma. The episodic nature of symptoms along with documented elevation in blood pressure during these episodes strongly supports this diagnosis.

Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • Dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor.

 

  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Addison's disease (Option A): Addison's disease is primary adrenocortical failure and presents with symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. While adrenal crisis can cause symptoms such as headache and sweating, it does not cause an episodic elevation of blood pressure and is characterized by hypotension rather than hypertension. Also elevated metanephrines is not a finding in Addison’s disease.

Renal artery stenosis (Option B): Renal artery stenosis can lead to high blood pressure but does not cause sudden onset headaches, palpitation, and profuse sweating. An elevated 24-hour urine metanephrine is not associated with renal artery stenosis as this condition affects the renovascular system rather than catecholamine production.

Hyperthyroidism (Option D): Hyperthyroidism symptoms include weight loss, increased appetite, tremors, heat intolerance, palpitations, and sweating. However, an elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine is not associated with hyperthyroidism, and the symptoms are typically continuous rather than episodic.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents with coarse facial features and gradual enlargement of the hands and feet for the past decade. He has been diagnosed with acromegaly based on elevated levels of IGF-1 and growth hormone that did not suppress after a 75 g glucose challenge test. What drug is recommended for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Lanreotide depot formulation

  • The clinical manifestations indicate active acromegaly based on typical physical changes and biochemical confirmation. Lanreotide is a somatostatin analog that has high efficacy in controlling GH and IGF-1 levels, as well as its convenient long duration of action.
  • It is administered as a long-acting depot injection and is considered the first line medical therapy for acromegaly. The medication works by binding to somatostatin receptors on the pituitary tumor, effectively reducing GH secretion and consequently normalizing IGF-1 levels.

Management of Acromegaly

Surgical Treatment

Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment, especially for those with GH-secreting adenomas.

Post-Surgery:

  • Improvement in soft tissue swelling and normalization of GH levels typically occur shortly after surgery
  • IGF-1 levels normalize within 3-4 days.
  • There is a 10% recurrence rate of acromegaly years later, and up to 15% of patients may develop hypopituitarism.

Medical therapy

Preferred in medical therapy if curative surgery is not feasible or if GH fails to decrease post resection

  • Somatostatin Receptor Ligands (SRLs):
    • Long-acting injectable forms (octreotide, lanreotide).
    • Normalizes GH and IGF-1 levels in about 50% of patients.
    • Side Effects: GI disturbances, transient nausea, and gallbladder issues.
  • GH receptor antagonist:
    • Pegvisomant blocks peripheral GH receptors, normalizing IGF-1 levels in about 70% of patients, though GH levels remain elevated. It is administered through daily subcutaneous injections and is used for recurrences or poor responses to SRLs.
  • Dopamine Agonists:
    • High doses of cabergoline can provide modest GH suppression.

Radiation Therapy

External beam radiation therapy or stereotactic techniques are considered for patients not achieving biochemical control through surgery or medical therapy.

Terlipressin (Option B): Terlipressin is a synthetic vasopressin analog used primarily for the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome and bleeding esophageal varices. It has no role in the treatment of acromegaly as it does not affect GH secretion or action.

Ketoconazole (Option C): Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication. While it has been used off-label for some endocrine conditions (such as adrenal hypercortisolism), it is not indicated for acromegaly management as it does not affect GH or IGF-1 levels.

Leuprolide (Option D): Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist commonly used for the treatment of conditions such as prostate cancer and endometriosis. It does not have any effect on GH secretion and is therefore not effective in treating acromegaly.

questions.text: A patient came to medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na+ levels were found to be 155 mEq/L, and his urine osmolarity was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management in this patient?

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

This patient's clinical presentation and history are consistent with central diabetes insipidus (DI), which results from insufficient vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone, ADH) secretion due to total hypophysectomy (removal of the pituitary gland). Key findings supporting this diagnosis include:

  • Polyuria (excessive urination) and low urine osmolarity (200 mOsm/L) indicate dilute urine, characteristic of diabetes insipidus.
  • Hypernatremia (Na⁺ = 155 mEq/L) suggests dehydration, commonly seen in DI due to impaired water retention.

Definitive management for central diabetes insipidus due to total hypophysectomy is lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation.

  • DDAVP is a synthetic analogue of vasopressin that helps reduce urine output and prevent dehydration. This treatment is required for the patient to manage the symptoms of DI and maintain fluid balance.

DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue (Option A): This is not appropriate for complete hypophysectomy, where the deficiency of vasopressin is permanent. Short-term DDAVP would only be used in cases where the deficiency is transient (e.g., partial hypophysectomy).

Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required (Option C): In central diabetes insipidus, the issue is the lack of vasopressin, not receptor dysfunction. Without treatment, the patient would experience chronic dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

Thiazides for 2 weeks (Option D): Thiazide diuretics may be used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (due to kidney resistance to ADH), but they are not effective in central DI, where the problem lies in vasopressin production, not renal response.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaints of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He has a complaint of sweaty palms. Clinical findings are depicted in the image given below. What is the diagnostic finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Thyroid receptor antibody

  • This patient's clinical presentation suggests Graves' disease, a form of hyperthyroidism. The symptoms, including palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and sweaty palms, are common in hyperthyroid states. The diagnostic finding in Graves' disease is elevated thyroid receptor antibodies. These antibodies, specifically thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to excess production of thyroid hormones, resulting in hyperthyroid symptoms.

Graves' Disease is an autoimmune disorder causing hyperthyroidism due to thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) that stimulate the thyroid gland, increasing hormone production (T3 and T4).

Clinical Features:

  • Hyperthyroid symptoms: Palpitations, sweating, restlessness, weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, hyperactivity, irritability.
  • Graves' ophthalmopathy: Exophthalmos, lid retraction, lid lag, conjunctival injection, dry eyes, visual disturbances.

Diagnosis:

  • Elevated TSI and thyroid function tests showing elevated T3/T4 and suppressed TSH.
  • Radioactive iodine uptake: Increased in Graves' disease.

Management:

  1. Antithyroid drugs: Propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole to inhibit thyroid hormone production.
  2. Radioactive iodine (RAI): Ablates overactive thyroid tissue but does not treat ophthalmopathy.
  3. Surgical treatment: Thyroidectomy if needed for large goiters or refractory cases.
  4. Graves' ophthalmopathy: Managed with corticosteroids, radiotherapy, or orbital decompression surgery for severe cases.

Anti-thyroglobulin antibody (Option A) and Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (Option B): These antibodies are elevated in conditions such as autoimmune hypothyroidism (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis).

Elevated ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels (Option D): TSH is typically low in hyperthyroid states like Graves' disease due to feedback inhibition, not elevated.

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Diltiazem

  • The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of thyroid storm (or thyroid crisis), a life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. The patient's symptoms, including severe restlessness, palpitations, tremors, tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and a swollen neck, are consistent with thyroid storm. The immediate priority is to control the heart rate due to the atrial fibrillation and high risk of complications such as heart failure.
  • In thyroid storm, beta-blockers like propranolol or esmolol are often used for rate control; however, they are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchospasm (Options B and C ruled out).
  • Instead, diltiazem, a calcium channel blocker, is the preferred option for rate control in this patient, as it does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects of beta-blockers.

Thyrotoxic crisis / Thyroid storm

Thyrotoxic crisis or thyroid storm

It is a life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism

Clinical features
  • Fever
  • Delirium, seizures, coma
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Jaundice
  • Hyperthermia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Arrhythmias

Precipitating factors

Precipitating factors:

Stress:

  • Acute illnesses like stroke, trauma, diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Surgery, commonly of the thyroid

Infections

  • Radioiodine treatment of a patient with partially or untreated hyperthyroidism
  • Iodinated contrast agents
  • Amiodarone administeration

Treatment

  • Management of the precipitating factors (digoxin, diuretics, & oxygen)
  • IV fluids and ice pack
  • Propylthiouracil (DOC)
  • Methimazole/carbimazole
  • Beta-blockers
  • Corticosteroids
  • Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate 

Propylthiouracil (PTU) (Option D): Propylthiouracil is used to inhibit the synthesis of thyroid hormones in thyroid storm and is the drug of choice for the management of thyroid storm. However, it should be given only after the rate of atrial fibrillation is controlled, as the primary goal in the acute setting is to stabilize the patient and manage the arrhythmia.

questions.text: A patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presented to the ER with hypotension. She was on medication for RA but abruptly stopped them. On examination, her HR = 110 bpm, BP is 80/40 mm Hg, blood sugar = 50 mg/dl, Na = 130 meq/L and K = 6.0 meq/L. What should be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydrocortisone

Explanation:

  • The scenario here is of Addisonian crisis (or adrenal crisis) that was triggered due to the abrupt cessation of medications for rheumatoid arthritis (glucocorticoids like prednisone). This is treated with intravenous hydrocortisone.

Clinical features of adrenal crisis
  • Circulatory shock

  • Hyperkalemia

Management of adrenal crisis:

questions.text: Patient present with large sweaty hands, macroglossia and frontal bossing. Select the best test for confirmation of the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - GH levels after glucose suppression:

  • 75g of oral glucose is administered and blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, and 120 minutes. Normally, glucose suppressess GH, If GH > 1ng/ml, it is confirmatory of acromegaly.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option C - IGF-2: IGF-2 is not typically used for diagnosing acromegaly. It is more relevant in conditions like certain tumors and is not a primary diagnostic marker for acromegaly.

Option B - Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1). IGF-1 levels are elevated in acromegaly due to the increased secretion of growth hormone. IGF-1 is a stable marker that reflects chronic exposure to growth hormone and is therefore used as the screening test for acromegaly.

questions.text: In a patient with type 1 diabetes at the 3rd stage of beta cell damage, which of the following conditions is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Autoimmune positive + dysglycemia:

  • In Stage 3 of type 1 diabetes, there is significant beta cell damage due to an ongoing autoimmune process, leading to dysglycemia (impaired glucose levels). At this stage, there is insufficient insulin production to maintain normal glucose levels, causing hyperglycemia, which characterizes dysglycemia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Autoimmune positive + normoglycemia: This situation is typically seen in the early stages of type 1 diabetes (Stage 1), where there is an autoimmune response against beta cells, but blood glucose levels remain normal because there is still enough insulin production to maintain glucose homeostasis.

Option B - Autoimmune negative + normoglycemia: This scenario is not associated with type 1 diabetes. In type 1 diabetes, the autoimmune process is the hallmark feature. If there are no autoimmune markers (autoantibodies), it suggests that type 1 diabetes is unlikely. Normoglycemia in such a context would also not indicate any beta cell damage typical of type 1 diabetes.

Option D - Autoimmune negative + dysglycemia: This condition is more suggestive of type 2 diabetes or other forms of diabetes where autoimmune destruction of beta cells is not present. Dysglycemia without autoimmunity does not fit with the progression of type 1 diabetes, which is defined by the presence of autoimmune markers.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea. D-xylose test was normal and the Schilling test was abnormal. A duodenal biopsy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pancreatic insufficiency:

  • Pancreatic insufficiency refers to the inadequate production or secretion of pancreatic enzymes, including lipase, amylase, and proteases. This can lead to malabsorption of nutrients, particularly fats, resulting in chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea (excessive fat in the stool). In this case, the patient's symptoms of chronic diarrhea and steatorrhea suggest impaired fat digestion and absorption.
  • The D-xylose test is used to assess the absorption of xylose, a sugar, in the small intestine and an abnormal Schilling test result suggests impaired absorption of vitamin B12.
  • An abnormal Schilling test result suggests impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Celiac disease: Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition characterized by an abnormal immune response to gluten, leading to damage to the small intestine.

Option B - Ulcerative colitis: Ulcerative colitis is a form of inflammatory bowel disease primarily affecting the colon and rectum.

Option C - Intestinal lymphangiectasia: Intestinal lymphangiectasia is a condition characterized by dilated lymphatic vessels in the intestinal wall, leading to the leakage of lymphatic fluid into the intestinal lumen.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Myxedema coma:

  • Myxedema coma is life threatening complication of hypothyroidism that is triggered by UTI, MI, Stroke, CHF, abuse of sedatives.
  • Patients with myxedema coma present with altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and signs of systemic decompensation. The symptoms of constipation, dry skin, and menorrhagia are also commonly associated with hypothyroidism.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Septic shock: Septic shock is a life-threatening condition caused by a severe infection leading to systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.

Option B - Cardiogenic shock: Cardiogenic shock occurs when the heart's ability to pump blood is severely compromised, leading to inadequate tissue perfusion.

Option D - Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar, can cause altered mental status and hypotension.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with a gradually diminishing visual field. She was found to have a pituitary mass and underwent trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy. Now she has low levels of ACTH, TSH, FSH and LH. Which of the following hormone supplements is not needed in the patient postoperatively?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mineralocorticoids:

  • Mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone, are responsible for regulating electrolyte and water balance in the body. They are not produced by the pituitary gland but rather by the adrenal cortex.
  • Therefore, the patient's deficiency in ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) will not directly affect mineralocorticoid production. Hence, mineralocorticoid supplementation is not needed in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thyroid hormones: Thyroid hormones, including TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone), play a crucial role in regulating metabolism. As the patient has low levels of TSH, indicating thyroid hormone deficiency, thyroid hormone supplementation is necessary to maintain normal thyroid function.

Option C - Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, are produced by the adrenal cortex under the stimulation of ACTH. With the deficiency of ACTH, the production of glucocorticoids is reduced. Therefore, glucocorticoid supplementation is needed to replace the deficient cortisol and provide the necessary physiological effects.

Option D - Estradiol: Estradiol is a female sex hormone produced primarily by the ovaries. The deficiency of FSH (follicle-stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinizing hormone) indicates dysfunction of the gonadotropins, which regulate the production of estradiol. Consequently, estradiol supplementation may be required to maintain hormonal balance in premenopausal women.

questions.text:
Which of the following joints are commonly involved in diabetes?

MC joint involved in diabetes is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Metatarsophalangeal joints: 

  • In diabetes, one of the commonly affected joints is the Charcot joint, particularly the metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints.
  • Charcot joint mainly involves the foot is frequently affected in individuals with diabetes.
  • Complications such as peripheral neuropathy, and poor circulation (peripheral arterial disease) can lead to foot-related issues such as ulcers, infections, and joint deformities.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Ankle- While complications of diabetes can affect the ankle joint indirectly, such as peripheral neuropathy leading to instability and increased risk of ankle injuries, the ankle joint itself is not a primary site of involvement in diabetes.

Option B - Knee- Diabetes can lead to various complications and conditions that may affect the knee joint indirectly, such as diabetic neuropathy or diabetic arthropathy (Charcot joint), but the knee joint itself is not a primary site of involvement.

Option C - Shoulder- Shoulder joint involvement is not commonly associated with diabetes. Diabetes-related joint problems typically manifest in weight-bearing joints and those subjected to excessive pressure, such as the foot.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of hypokalemia, hypertension, and metabolic alkalosis in a 35-year-old female patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Liddle’s syndrome:

  • Liddle's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a defect in epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) exhibiting a gain of function.
  • Liddle's syndrome is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects the loop of Henle in the kidney and leads to salt wasting, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

Option B- Gitelman's syndrome: Gitelman's syndrome is another genetic disorder that affects the distal convoluted tubules of the kidney and results in hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hypomagnesemia.

Option D- Fanconi's syndrome: Fanconi's syndrome is a condition characterized by dysfunction of the proximal tubules of the kidney, leading to hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, and other electrolyte abnormalities can occur.

questions.text: In a medical camp established on a military base, a 20-year-old military recruit is discovered to have an HbA1C level of 6.1% and a fasting blood glucose of 120 mg/dL. The individual does not have a familial background of diabetes mellitus and displays no indications or symptoms of diabetes. The general physical examination shows no noteworthy findings. Which of the following options most accurately characterizes the blood glucose levels in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Impaired Glucose tolerance: 

  • The patient in the scenario has an HbA1C level of 6.1% and a fasting blood glucose level of 120 mg/dL. These values fall within the range that indicates impaired glucose tolerance (IGT).
  • Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) is a condition in which blood glucose levels are higher than normal but not high enough to be classified as diabetes mellitus.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Normal- Normal blood glucose levels typically fall within a range of 70-99 mg/dL for fasting blood glucose and below 5.7% for HbA1C.

Option C - Diabetes Mellitus- Diabetes mellitus is diagnosed when fasting blood glucose levels are consistently above 126 mg/dL or HbA1C levels are equal to or higher than 6.5%.

Option D - Maturity onset diabetes in Young (MODY)- Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is a type of diabetes characterized by a strong family history, early onset before the age of 25, and a specific genetic etiology.

questions.text: A 25-year-old P1L1 woman is planning for her second child. She has been recently diagnosed with Grave’s disease. Which of the following is the antithyroid drug to be used in early gestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Propylthiouracil:

  • Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism, which results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland.
  • Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug that works by inhibiting the production of thyroid hormones. PTU is the preferred drug for use during early pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, as it has a lower risk of causing birth defects compared to Methimazole.

 

Incorrect choices:

Option B - Methimazole is also an antithyroid drug that works by inhibiting the production of thyroid hormones. Methimazole is usually avoided during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its potential risk of causing birth defects. However, it can be used during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy if PTU is not well-tolerated.

Option C - Carbimazole is a prodrug of Methimazole. Like Methimazole, it is avoided during the first trimester of pregnancy due to the risk of causing birth defects.

Option D - Propylthiouracil can be used in early gestation, but Methimazole and Carbimazole are avoided during the first trimester of the pregnancy.

questions.text: What should be done next in the management of a patient who is diabetic and presents with symptoms of vomiting and abdominal pain? Upon examination, the patient displays hyperventilation, sweet breath, and low blood pressure. The blood glucose level is 320 mg/dL, and urine ketones are detected.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IVF and check K+:

  • The patient in the given scenario presents with symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a potentially life-threatening complication of diabetes.
  • Patients with DKA are typically dehydrated due to excessive urination and vomiting, and they also lose potassium in the urine. Hypokalemia (low potassium levels) can occur due to insulin therapy, so it is important to check and monitor potassium levels closely during treatment.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A - IV insulin drip is a necessary treatment for DKA. Still, it should be initiated after fluid resuscitation to avoid causing a sudden drop in blood glucose levels, which can lead to cerebral edema.

Option B - IV soda-bicarbonate is not recommended for the initial management of DKA as it may worsen the acidosis by causing a shift in the acid-base balance.

Option C - While checking blood ketone levels is important for diagnosing DKA, it does not address the acute management of the condition.

questions.text: Calcitonin is a marker of which malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Medullary thyroid cancer:

  • Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the C-cells (also known as parafollicular cells) of the thyroid gland. Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland.
  • Calcitonin is the tumour marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Papillary thyroid cancer: Papillary thyroid cancer arises from the follicular cells of the thyroid gland, not the parafollicular C-cells.

Option B - Follicular thyroid cancer: Similar to papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer also arises from the follicular cells of the thyroid gland and does not usually result in elevated calcitonin levels.

Option D - Anaplastic thyroid cancer: Anaplastic thyroid cancer is an aggressive and rare form of thyroid cancer that is not typically associated with elevated calcitonin levels. It arises from the follicular cells of the thyroid gland, similar to papillary and follicular thyroid cancers.

questions.text: 70 year old man presents with low back ache and progressive pallor. On work up, KFT is deranged. LFT is normal with normal level of Albumin, but gamma globulins are disproportionately increased. X ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following is the cell of origin of the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Plasma cell:

  • The clinical presentation of low back ache, progressive pallor, deranged KFT, disproportionately increased gamma globulins, and lytic lesions on X-ray spine is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma, a cancer of plasma cells.
  • In multiple myeloma, abnormal plasma cells accumulate in the bone marrow and produce excessive amounts of a single type of immunoglobulin, leading to lytic bone lesions and other symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lymphocyte: They can give rise to lymphomas, but lymphomas typically present as lymph node enlargements and may involve other organs.

Option C - Histiocytes: Diseases involving histiocytes include Langerhans cell histiocytosis and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, but these conditions typically present with different clinical features and are not consistent with the provided symptoms and findings.

Option D - Monocytes: Monocytes are another type of white blood cell involved in the immune response and can differentiate into macrophages and dendritic cells.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urine metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Pheochromocytoma:

  • Pheochromocytoma produces excessive amounts of catecholamines, leading to symptoms like sudden onset headache, palpitation and profuse sweating.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated levels of urinary metanephrines.
  • A 24-hour urine metanephrine test is a diagnostic test for pheochromocytoma. 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Addison's disease: It presents with symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. While adrenal crisis can cause symptoms such as headache and sweating, it does not cause an episodic elevation of blood pressure.

Option B - Renal artery stenosis: It can lead to high blood pressure but does not cause sudden onset headaches, palpitation, and profuse sweating. An elevated 24-hour urine metanephrine is not associated with renal artery stenosis.

Option D - Hyperthyroidism: Hyperthyroidism symptoms include weight loss, increased appetite, tremors, heat intolerance, palpitations, and sweating. An elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine is not associated with hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: Which condition is frequently linked to Addison's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autoimmune adrenalitis:

  • This is the correct answer. Addison's disease, also known as primary adrenal insufficiency, is commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis. In this condition, the body's immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys the adrenal cortex, leading to inadequate production of adrenal hormones.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Adrenocortical carcinoma - Adrenocortical carcinoma is a rare malignant tumor of the adrenal cortex. While it can cause adrenal hormone imbalances, it is not commonly associated with Addison's disease.

Option C - Hypernephroma - Hypernephroma is an outdated term for renal cell carcinoma, which is a type of kidney cancer. It is unrelated to Addison's disease.

Option D - Medullary carcinoma thyroid - Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C cells. It is not associated with Addison's disease.

questions.text: What is the treatment for hypercalcemia caused by vitamin D toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dexamethasone:

  • Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that can be used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity. It works by reducing intestinal calcium absorption and promoting renal calcium excretion.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine main uses are in the treatment of malaria and certain autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

Option C - Chloroquine: Similar to hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine is an antimalarial drug and is not commonly used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity.

Option D - Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is primarily used in the treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered tumor in the anterior mediastinum?

Thymoma is the most common tumor in the anterior mediastinum. Thymomas are malignant epithelial cell tumors that form in the Thymus. They are commonly found in the perivascular or anterior mediastinum.

questions.text: Gynecomastia results from an imbalance between androgen and oestrogen activity. All of the below are causes of gynecomastia, except.

questions.text: Which prolactin levels are indicative of prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D >200µg/L

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of fulminant diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Viruses:

  • Fulminant diabetes, also known as fulminant type 1 diabetes or acute-onset type 1 diabetes, is a rare and rapidly progressing form of diabetes characterized by severe hyperglycemia and a rapid loss of insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas.
  • Viruses, particularly enteroviruses such as Coxsackie B virus, have been implicated as a potential cause of fulminant diabetes. These viruses can infect and damage the pancreatic beta cells, leading to their destruction and subsequent loss of insulin production.

Incorrect options

Option B -Diabetic Ketoacidosis 

  • DKA occurs primarily in individuals with established diabetes, particularly in type 1 diabetes, and is characterized by the presence of hyperglycemia, ketosis, and acidosis.

Option C - Non-ketotic Hyperosmolar Coma

  • Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma is characterized by extremely high blood glucose levels and severe dehydration. However, it is not the most common cause of fulminant diabetes.

Option D - Autoimmunity

  • In the case of fulminant diabetes, the rapid onset and progression of the disease suggest a different underlying cause, such as viral infection, rather than the gradual autoimmune destruction of beta cells seen in typical type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: Which type of insulin should be administered to manage a 32-year-old male patient with a medical history of peptic ulcer disease and diabetes mellitus, who presents to the emergency department complaining of nausea, abdominal pain, and lethargy for the past two days? The patient also reports occasional dark, tarry stools. Laboratory tests indicate elevated blood glucose levels and a high anion gap metabolic acidosis on an arterial blood gas sample.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Regular insulin: 

  • Regular insulin, also known as short-acting insulin, is the most appropriate choice for managing DKA.
  • Regular insulin is the correct choice because it has an onset of action of approximately 30 minutes, peaks in 2 to 4 hours, and lasts for about 6 to 8 hours. Its slower onset and longer duration of action make it suitable for managing the prolonged hyperglycemia and metabolic acidosis associated with DKA.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Lispro insulin is a rapid-acting insulin with a quick onset of action but a shorter duration compared to regular insulin. It is commonly used to manage postprandial glucose spikes in individuals with diabetes.

Option C - Glargine insulin is a long-acting insulin that provides a steady release of insulin over an extended period (approximately 24 hours). It is used for basal insulin coverage. .

Option D - Aspart insulin is a rapid-acting insulin similar to lispro insulin. It has a rapid onset and shorter duration of action, making it less suitable for the management of DKA

questions.text: Which of the following has a slow onset of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: 

  • Glargine insulin is a long-acting insulin that is characterized by a slow onset of action, typically taking about 1 to 2 hours to begin working. It is designed to provide a steady release of insulin over an extended period (approximately 24 hours). This slow onset and prolonged duration make it suitable for providing basal insulin coverage.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Lispro insulin is a rapid-acting insulin that has a quick onset of action, typically within 15 minutes of administration. It is used to control postprandial glucose spikes after meals. Unlike glargine, lispro insulin has a fast onset rather than a slow onset.

Option C: Regular insulin, also known as short-acting insulin, has an onset of action of approximately 30 minutes. It is used for mealtime coverage or in combination with long-acting insulin for basal coverage. It is not characterized by a slow onset like glargine.

Option D: NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin. It has a slower onset compared to rapid-acting insulins but is not specifically known for having a slow onset like glargine. NPH insulin typically takes about 1 to 2 hours to start working

questions.text: What is the main physical finding of prolactinoma that follows galactorrhea in a 19-year-old nulligravida woman who has been experiencing milk discharge from her nipples for the last 5 months and is diagnosed with prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bitemporal hemianopia: 

  • Prolactinomas are benign pituitary tumors that secrete excessive prolactin. When large enough, they can compress the optic chiasm, where optic nerve fibers partially cross. This pressure disrupts the outer (temporal) visual fields of both eyes, leading to bitemporal hemianopia—a condition where patients lose peripheral vision but retain central vision. Bitemporal hemianopia is a key physical finding in large prolactinomas and often prompts further diagnostic imaging to confirm the tumor's presence.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Anovulatory cycles- While prolactinomas can disrupt normal menstrual cycles, leading to anovulatory cycles, it is not the characteristic physical finding after galactorrhea.

Option C: Amenorrhea- Prolactinomas can cause hormonal imbalances, including elevated prolactin levels, which can disrupt normal menstrual cycles and lead to amenorrhea. However, it is not the characteristic physical finding after galactorrhea.

Option D: Infertility- Prolactinomas can disrupt normal hormonal balance and interfere with ovulation, leading to difficulties in conceiving. However, infertility is not the characteristic physical finding after galactorrhea

questions.text: Tumor Lysis Syndrome is an oncological emergency presenting with all of the below except.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypophosphatemia:

  • Hypophosphatemia: During TLS, there is a rapid release of intracellular phosphate from lysed cells, leading to an increase in serum phosphate levels (hyperphosphatemia) rather than a decrease.

Incorrect options

Option  B - Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia is commonly observed in Tumor Lysis Syndrome. The increased phosphate levels caused by tumor lysis can bind to calcium, resulting in a decrease in ionized calcium levels.

Option  C - Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia is a characteristic feature of Tumor Lysis Syndrome. The release of purines from the breakdown of DNA in tumor cells leads to increased uric acid production.

Option D - Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is frequently seen in Tumor Lysis Syndrome. The release of intracellular potassium from lysed cells, combined with impaired renal excretion, can result in increased serum potassium levels.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of elevated serum Calcium levels in a patient with normal SAP, PTH, and Vitamin D3 levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Multiple myeloma:

  • Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer that involves plasma cells in the bone marrow. It can lead to the excessive production of monoclonal immunoglobulins (M-protein), which can cause hypercalcemia. In multiple myeloma, the serum calcium levels can be elevated while SAP, PTH, and vitamin D3 levels remain normal.

Incorrect options

Option A - Vitamin D intoxication: In cases of vitamin D intoxication, both serum calcium and vitamin D3 levels are typically elevated. The PTH levels are usually suppressed due to the feedback mechanism between vitamin D and PTH.

Option B - Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by increased PTH levels, which stimulate the release of calcium from bone, resulting in elevated serum calcium levels. In this case, since PTH levels are normal, hyperparathyroidism is not the likely diagnosis.

Option D - Nutritional rickets: This option is incorrect. Nutritional rickets is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In this case, serum calcium levels would typically be decreased rather than elevated.

questions.text: In obesity, there is an increase in the production of which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Insulin:

  • Insulin: Obesity is associated with insulin resistance, a condition in which the body's cells become less responsive to the effects of insulin. In response to insulin resistance, the pancreas produces and releases more insulin to compensate for the decreased effectiveness. This increased insulin production is a characteristic feature of obesity.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thyroxine (T4)

  • Thyroid hormones, including thyroxine, are involved in regulating metabolism. While obesity can affect thyroid function, it typically does not cause a direct increase in thyroxine production.

Option C - Growth hormone

  • Growth hormone (GH) levels may be altered in obesity, but the relationship is complex. In some cases, obese individuals may have reduced GH secretion or impaired response to GH. However, it is not a consistent finding that GH production is increased in obesity.

Option D - Adiponectin

  • Adiponectin is an adipokine, a hormone secreted by adipose tissue. Its production is generally decreased in obesity, rather than increased. Lower levels of adiponectin are associated with insulin resistance and other metabolic abnormalities seen in obesity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with complaints of bone pain in the hands, difficulty in passing stools, along with history of recurrent renal stones. On investigation, his serum calcium was increased, decreased serum phosphate and X-ray showing subperiosteal resorption of phalanges. In which of the following conditions calcitonin levels are increased?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the parafollicular or C-cells of the thyroid gland. Its primary function is to regulate calcium and phosphate levels in the body.
  • In hyperparathyroidism, there is excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands. This condition leads to increased levels of PTH, which in turn can stimulate the production of calcitonin by the thyroid gland.  

Incorrect Options:

Hyperthyroidism (option A) is characterized by an overactive thyroid gland and is not directly associated with increased calcitonin levels.

Hypoparathyroidism (option B) is a condition where there is an underproduction of parathyroid hormone, leading to decreased levels of PTH and subsequently decreased calcitonin levels.

Cushing's syndrome (option D) is a disorder caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol hormone, typically due to adrenal gland dysfunction. It is not directly associated with changes in calcitonin levels.
